review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2020
review.title: Great mouse, as advertised
review.review: Was a bit wary going in buying a renewed product, but there was no need. Mouse and 3 grip attachments came safely packaged in great condition. People have complained about the iCUE software, but I don't find it too difficult so long as you do a little bit of research to help yourself out. One important note on that; you can change both the "hardware actions/lighting" settings (the default behavior of the lights and programmable buttons when iCUE is NOT running, and have to be saved to the mouse when changed) and the regular "actions/lighting" settings (those that take over when iCUE is running, and you can set up different profiles to switch between). The nice thing is you can customize the mouse to your liking and have those settings saved without having iCUE running, or if you need the mouse to be able to adapt to different programs/games etc... you can leave iCUE running and it'll take care of it without needing to re-open the settings and adjust each time.When it comes to the mouse itself, I'm enjoying it so far. Mouse wheel has nice texture and is very responsive, and the two side buttons are in a great spot depending on your grip; and if you prefer one over the other depending on your grip you can easily customize them. On that, it's worth noting; the two side buttons default to serving as the "back" and "forward" features when navigating the internet which is a nice feature, but you can easily change it if you like. The two buttons in front of the mouse wheel are labelled as the DPI buttons and their default function changes between different DPI levels; however you can also remap these buttons in the same way.The lighting customization is a bit tricky to figure out only because of how many options there are. I'm content with just 1 or 2 solid lights, but the combinations are extensive. Also of note is that the 5 lit bars on the top indicate the DPI profiles you can switch between, and the lighting settings for them is separate in the DPI section of iCUE. The one common complaint I've seen noted is that the lights tend to get warm, but I've found that turning the brightness of the lighting down in the general iCUE settings has prevented this issue so far for me.I have generally larger hands and the mouse fits me reasonably well. I used to use a wrist rest for my mouse but, again depending on the grip, I have found the mouse just as, if not more, comfortable to use without the wrist rest. I don't really have a "go-to" grip so to speak, but so far I'd say I've favored a fingertip grip thus far, and is just as comfortable with a full palm grip; the mouse has a very ergonomic shape if this is what you favor, I find it very comfortable.Very important but also quite silly, there is plastic over all the pads on the bottom of the mouse and the bottom of the largest grip attachment... but the plastic is so thin and subtle that I didn't notice them at first. Once one of them started to roll up on the bottom and I then peeled them all off the mouse felt much smoother.

review.review: Whether a mouse costs $10 or $200, is rated 1 Stars or 5 Stars is entirely determined by user preference and perceived ergonomics of said mouse.I have run the gambit of pointing devices including trackballs cheap and expensive.When my beloved Mad Catz Pro, The Authentic R.A.T mouse finally died after years of hard toiling and when the mourning period of its death was over I considered another brand. I had used Corsair products before and was very satisfied was their quality and in my mouse search found this little "gem" the CorsairGlaive PRO.I guess at 67 years old I need a more conservative-looking mouse instead of one that looks at home on a Klingon battlecruiser. Not saying the Glaive PRO is a "grandpa" mouse as it delivers great performance and is easy on the pocketbook. Durability will be the big unknown in this purchase as I have never owned a Corsair mouse. So far it is proving to be a very good value. Though not a Mad Catz with an assortment of accessories including customizable weights to get that ultimate "gamer" feel the Corsair Glaive PRO doesn't cost $200+ either which is enough to make any Grandpa smile. It does have three thumb rest pieces that attach securely magnetically, however. Your comfort will be entirely determined by how "happy" your hand feels using it, no two people are exactly the same.The Glaive is very comfortable as I use the larger (wider) thumb rest and the software offered at Corsair's website works admirably.Arthritis in my fingers frequently causes me to press the right button with my middle finger as my index presses the left button inadvertently this affliction of advancing years is mediated with the Corsair Glaive's rounded drop off at the front. I still miss the metal body construction of the Mad Catz (it was built like a tank) and will for some time to come but it's a minor adjustment as the Corsair Glaive is filling in quite nicely.

review.title: Didn't expect would be that good
review.review: This is the kind of product you are not sure you really need until you get it and wonder how you could manage to live without it. With all the not so good reviews, especially about the screen, I hesitated for a long time before to buy it but when I got some money as a gift from a aunt I decided to try it.First of all, the device looks very good quality and it sticks very well to my K95. The buttons and widgets are easy to setup with iCUE and you can configure them as you like (color, size, background image, etc.). You can only set 6 buttons per screen but you can set as many screens as you want and it's easy to switch between them by swiping with your finger. I switched from a two monitors setup to a single 32" one a year ago and I was missing very much to be able to monitor my temperatures while gaming without having to run some overlay programs. Turns out that thing does it wonderfully well.Unlike some other people said I didn't notice any increase of CPU usage after I connected it (but maybe it's because my Ryzen 5900x just doesn't feel it).About the screen, it's true that if you look at it from an angle you don't see anything anymore but... this thing is not supposed to be looked at from a 45 degree angle. It is supposed to be watched when you are in front of your keyboard and when you do that it's amazingly clear and bright. My only negative point is that the touch functionality when you press a button is not always super reactive but I realize that it works fine if you aim more toward the bottom of the screen instead of the top. In that way it works just fine.Overall, it's an expansive device but for me it worth it. Really awesome gadget to have in your setup.

When there's a new update, every time you log in to your computer, even after waking it of sleep, the big neon green Razer Central screen jumps out at you to tell you that there are app updates. "Fine", you think, "I'll just disable auto updates"'. There's even an option to do so in the settings. The problem? It. Doesn't. Work. It will keep on pestering you every single time they release some update, which happens every week or two. And what's worse, every update requires a reboot. If you don't reboot? It will keep pestering you. Disable the Razer services? The big Razer logo on the mouse will glow a bright, neon green. I've seen discussions on the forums about what firewall ports to disable in order to prevent Razer's apps from phoning home, but that's really way more trouble than I'm willing to go through for a mouse.Simply the worst experience with software I can remember in a very long time. The mouse itself is okay, but just not worth the hassle. I'm looking for something better - and NOT by Razer.
